title: Case studies: organisations being more open and trusted with data
displayTitle: Case studies: organisations being more open and trusted with data
mobileInstruction: Click '+' to explore each case study

_items.title: Increasing online sales
_items.body:
Competing for sales in the online market is tough. There are now a large number of channels that can be used to reach potential customers including dynamic paid search, story campaigns and even direct-buy buttons that can be embedded by review websites, on blogs, and in other social media.

These all rely on real-time product data including prices and (increasingly) availability. We are seeing retailers being increasingly open with their product data, helping it reach new channels, enabling them to be more visible and competitive in the marketplace.

_items.title: Building a platform for data flows
_items.body: Amazon realised early that parts of the business that collected data and held it in silos could prevent it from realising the most value from data. Amazon also realised that it should design these services to also be available externally, enabling organisations and individuals to use the data to innovate. Amazon now provides the data infrastructure for hundreds of companies who use it to connect to their markets and grow their businesses.
_items.strapline: Building a platform for data flows

_items.title: Winning awards for ethical data practices
_items.body:
In 2019, Co-op was awarded the DatalQ Award for Best Data Ethics and Privacy Programme.

In an era where data is increasingly crucial to commercial success and customers are growing more aware of how data about them is used, this award recognises Co-op colleagues’ commitment to being trusted with the data about its members, customers, and communities, which helps ensure that the business makes informed and ethical decisions that support its values.

Co-op, which offers a diverse range of products and services, used the Open Data Institute’s Data Ethics Canvas to empower teams and help them identify and manage ethical issues when using data, while building data literacy.
_items.strapline: Winning awards for ethical data practices

title: Where data sits in our landscape
body:
Some of the most challenging problems and exciting opportunities lie at the intersections between human behaviour and technological innovation. Digital twins unleash value by enabling better decisions — in use, operations, maintenance, resilience, planning, investment and more — across the built and natural environments. However, in a world where the collection of data is accelerating, the value of the information it can provide is limited by the lack of a strategy for interconnections, resilience or long-term outcomes. We need a sociotechnical change programme to ensure alignment under a principled, people led approach.

The key is to collect high-quality data and make it available for everyone to use. Much that we take for granted today is only possible because of agreed and open standards and mechanism that enable global interoperability of data.  Take standards like barcodes, energy delivery and even passports. These are agreed standards with international agreement on how complex data ecosystems operate.

title: The data landscape and connected digital twins
body:
A digital twin is a digital representation of a physical asset, process or system. It is distinguished from any other digital model by its dynamic connection to the physical twin. 

Digital twins are tools to make better decision, faster and quicker by going through the information value chain more efficiently – turning data into insights that enable improved decisions and provide better outcomes.

Data plays a fundamental role in enable secure, resilient and connected digital twins. 

However, to realise the full benefits that data can bring, businesses must understand the ‘data landscape’ and its role in connected digital twins.

title: Where next?
body:
To help everyone discover more we have developed several modules to help overcome barriers to sharing data in the digital twins landscape and enable the construction of a shared data infrastructure.

These modules focus on:

  1. How to share data across organisational and sectoral boundaries

  2. Understanding the spectrum of data and our roles and responsibilities when sharing and consuming data from third parties

  3. Protecting the rights of individuals while maximising the utility of data

  4. Ensuring interoperability of data in the digital twins ecosystem

  5. Applying data ethics to ensure our twins are “good”

 

Data sharing across organisational and sectoral boundaries

Value can be created from data when it is collected, accessed, used and shared. Maximising the value created from data can only be achieved when all of these aspects are considered. However this cycle is often broken as data is not shared and thus the same data cannot be collected and re-used by others. One the main reasons data is not shared is the lack of clear data sharing agreement or licence that can be used to safely shared data while protecting the interests of the data owner.

This module introduces the key role of data sharing agreements and data licenses as ways to safely share data and maximise its reuse.

 

Protecting the rights of individuals while maximising the utility of data

Fears over collecting, using and sharing personal data often results in data not getting to those who need it. The challenge starts with understanding just what personal data is, the difference between this and sensitive commercial data, and the role of data protection regulations, which many see as a blocker to collecting, using and sharing personal data. 

The aim of this module is to increase understanding of personal data and techniques that can be applied to ensure the rights of individuals are protected, while maximising the utility of data.

 

Working with data from third party sources

Data increases in value the more it is connected. This is because allowing data to be collected, used and shared means it can be utilised for a number of purposes.

However, before any data can be collected, used or shared, it is important to understand who owns what data, who has rights over it and what permissions or responsibilities you or others have in relation to the data. Projects that set out with good intentions to reuse existing data often encounter legal and ethical constraints which should be addressed as soon as possible.

This module looks at the spectrum of data and how permission is granted and/or obtained to integrate, analyse and otherwise reuse data.

How can connected digital twins be interoperable? 

In order to build a shared data infrastructure, it is critical that data is as interoperable as possible. This goes beyond simply using the same standard or set of column titles. In this module we explore the following:

  • Legal interoperability

  • Technical interoperability

  • Semantic interoperability

 

Applying data ethics

In this module we will explore the application of data ethics using tools that support individuals and organisations in developing products and services that mitigate negative risks and serve to promote positive outcomes for people and society. 

This module provides you with the knowledge and skills to:

1. Describe the types of questions to ask when embedding ethical data practices

2. Identify common barriers to adopting approaches to data ethics

3. Explain how to use tools and frameworks to support ethical thinking around collection, use and sharing of data in projects

4. Make several recommendations to improve the ethical handling of data

title: Common barriers (1): Hoarding data
body:
One of the biggest challenges to realising the full value of data is the lack of cultural willingness to share data. The ODI calls this scenario ‘the oil field’.

The oil field is a scenario where: owning data; having as much data as possible in one place; trying to know everything about everyone and then maintaining the inevitable degradation of these datasets – is killing the return on investment (and the fun!) when working with  data, and it’s not the only way!

Such approaches lead to a closed (or walled garden) environment which can greatly reduce innovation capabilities.

To overcome this barrier, organisations should support an open culture as much as possible. During challenging times it is especially important to realise the benefits of working with others, sharing insights and innovating together.

Building a data catalog that we can all use helps ensure variety is our data superpower. It also helps to prevent hoarding and the inevitable associated degradation of data.

title: Data is infrastructure
body:
Building data infrastructure is not as simple as putting data on a server or in a spreadsheet. You need to build a strong foundation that sets out priorities. 

At level one, this involves having a clear strategy, aligned to the legal and ethical frameworks that ensure fair and equitable development of that infrastructure. You also ensure you are investing in the infrastructure and the capability to manage it. 

One top of a strong foundation you build the data infrastructure itself. A data infrastructure consists of data assets, supported by people, policies and process and technology. 

From this infrastructure you can build value. But to get there requires the building of trust. Changes to infrastructure (even physical) require large change management programmes to build trust in them and the value they provide as a result. It is critical to engage openly for people to understand the value which often requires large amounts of investment.

title: Creating impact with data
body:
Value is created when we collect, manage and share data in ways that support creative transformation.

For example, recently we have seen how data can be used to: deliver £14m of sales for a large supermarket chain; demonstrate how nearly all modern music has roots in Tennessee; and create dynamic and unique brand experiences for music venues. You can find out more about these and other case studies in the next module.

Clients should be able to rely on our data expertise to deliver creative transformation because they trust us: to be responsible with data; to hold ourselves accountable for the data-driven decisions we are making; and to do our best to protect our clients.

To realise the value of data we need to develop the culture, capabilities and infrastructure that help ensure data is not siloed, and enable it to be used alongside other data.

title: Common barriers (2): Fearing data
body:
If data is unused and unloved, it will degrade and could potentially lead to security risks, reputational and brand damage. The ODI calls this scenario ‘the wasteland’.

The wasteland is most prevalent in situations where unaddressed fears arising from legitimate concerns – such as who has access to data and how it might be used – prevent any benefits being realised.

The ODI recommends putting in place practices that ensure the way data is collected and used is trustworthy and just.

To help address these fears WPP Open is developing a set of Data Ethics Principles and Guidelines that will be rolled out in each agency to ensure there is equity around who accesses, uses and benefits from data.

title: Creating impact with data and digital twins
displayTitle: Creating impact with data and digital twins
body:
Value is created when we collect, manage and share data to enable better decisions and interventions such as:

  • Is it possible to avoid building a new hospital carpark by managing appointment times and traffic flows?

  • Reduce energy consumption through the more intelligent connection between devices that produce, store and consumer energy, e.g. solar, wind, batteries and EVs.

  • Increase the efficiency of traffic flows based upon live factors such as accidents, events, or weather conditions.

title: The role of connected digital twins
body:
“Data increases in value the more it is connected” - ODI 2017

Connected digital twins, are tools to understand the complexities of interconnected systems and provide better insights to enable better decisions and interventions.

An ecosystem of digital twins, connected by data, breaks down the complexities of understanding the system as a whole. This system-based outlook will help understand the knock-on effects and the trade-offs that a decision could cause. By connecting physical assets, processes and systems with shared digital connections and data, we will gain insights that will enable improvements, optimisations, and better interventions across scales.
